review: I was totally swept up in this novel about prohibition-era New England. The first scene is a real nail-biter, and I was impressed by how quickly movedI was totally swept up in this novel about prohibition-era New England. The first scene is a real nail-biter, and I was impressed by how quickly moved I was by the characters and their plight. I LOVED the sweeping narrative style and the way Solomon so deftly moved from one character to another. There's a lot of good thematic stuff here about motherhood, mental illness, poverty--and it's also a compelling story with a juicy plot. (Side note: the disturbing image of a little girl getting secretly pinched by her (not actual) father won't leave me anytime soon.)...more

title: A Little Life
author: Yanagihara, Hanya*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this book far more quickly that I thought I would. I feel wrung out now. It's beautiful and profound, and at times so brutal I could barely keeI read this book far more quickly that I thought I would. I feel wrung out now. It's beautiful and profound, and at times so brutal I could barely keep reading. I sobbed and sobbed while reading the last 150 pages or so. It's been a long time since I felt so close to fictional characters. At first, I felt the novel's withholding of information was too designed by the author, but eventually it began to feel more natural and right, and I loved how the book I thought I was reading--about 4 college friends--became something far different, far scarier, far deeper, and far more meaningful. This is petty, but I had a hard time with some of the names. I mean, a first name like Citizen--and no one mentions its oddness? What's also odd is the lack of historical/social/technological/political context for these lives--for covering so much time, we get very little texture outside of their private worlds. But that was also beautiful, in a way. ...more

title: The Unwinding: An Inner History of the New America
author: Packer, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book devastated and educated me about the changes in America in the last 40 years. It's phenomenal. I just finished writing a piece on The MillioThis book devastated and educated me about the changes in America in the last 40 years. It's phenomenal. I just finished writing a piece on The Millions about the third person, and had I read this before that, I would have suggested Packer's book as his voice and writing style alters with each new person he's writing about and following--it's lovely.I thought a couple of the passages about famous people were dripping with a bit too much cynicism for my taste; the one on Oprah was just plain mean (even if I agree with a lot of what he says, he seemed to always attribute self-serving motives to her actions, which felt too easy.) It's interesting to me that Packer can bring so much compassion and empathy to the subjects he meets and shadows, but not for the celebrities. This quibble didn't keep me from loving and admiring this book, which, man, depressed the hell out of me and made me wonder why I vote at all. ...more

title: The Book of Strange New Things
author: Faber, Michel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I liked a lot of this, and I keep coming back to certain details: the way the rain and the air feels to the humans on Oasis; the descriptions of the OI liked a lot of this, and I keep coming back to certain details: the way the rain and the air feels to the humans on Oasis; the descriptions of the Oasans' language--at one point they make a sound like "a finger cleaving ripe fruit" (I'm paraphrasing) which I loved so so much; the longing and disconnection between Peter and Bea, his wife. This novel really gets at how challenging distance can be between a couple and I felt Peter's frustration and disconnection, as well as Bea's longing and deep resentment. I was also caught up in Peter's missionary work and these intriguing Jesus Lovers. Certain revelations (ha, pun intended) about the planet's alien species left me breathless.I kept imagining Peter and Bea as older, in their sixties, and I had a very hard time shaking that--my own problem, I know. The novel felt about 100 pages too long overall, like it could have been swifter in various places. I wanted the novel very badly to return to Earth, but I get that's not what Faber had in mind.So, not a perfect book for me, but nevertheless haunting and weird and moving. ...more

author: Hugo, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I bought this book at Elliott Bay in Seattle, lured by the new cover. I'd heard so many things about it from other writers and writing teachers, and wI bought this book at Elliott Bay in Seattle, lured by the new cover. I'd heard so many things about it from other writers and writing teachers, and was glad to finally read the thing myself. I loved the first half--Hugo says a lot of wise stuff about the triggering subject, and about the way words sound. There's a great exercise, too, which I may try someday when my fiction needs a jolt of poetry. The latter half felt somewhat unfocused, as books that are really a collection of lectures can sometimes feel, but overall I enjoyed this one and would like to return to it as a teacher and a writer....more

author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book, and I think it's the best of Emily St. John Mandel's novels. I liked the shifting back and forth in time, and in a way it reminded I loved this book, and I think it's the best of Emily St. John Mandel's novels. I liked the shifting back and forth in time, and in a way it reminded me of A Visit From The Goon Squad. It's a really moving, human novel.I just did a panel with Emily at the Texas Book Festival and it was really fun to talk about what was similar and different in our novels. I'd put off reading other post-apocalypse novels since writing my own since, well, I was a bit sick of being in such a universe for years, but it was satisfying to see how it was handled here. My only small complaint was that the book seemed a little too enamored with social media. For instance, in the stunning, oft-quoted passage about what the flu has taken away ("No more blank, no more blank..."), it felt a little too heavily-weighted to the loss of the internet. There were a few times where the book seemed a bit too wide-eyed about the miracles of technology. But that's just a quibble......more

title: Tin Star        (Tin Star, #1)
author: Castellucci, Cecil*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have never ever read straight-up outer space science fiction so this was a new and exciting reading experience for me. I loved the book's heroine, TI have never ever read straight-up outer space science fiction so this was a new and exciting reading experience for me. I loved the book's heroine, Tula Bane, and I found her isolation, anger and pain devastating and moving. I loved her friendship with one particular alien who teaches her how to make deals and get favors out of other species on the space station. The plot really started to rev up a third of the way through and I devoured it...intergalactic politics! a love interest! My goodness! I can't wait for the sequel!I was especially interested in the book's ideas of what it means to be human--the good and the horrible. I am still thinking about that, days after finishing the book.My one complaint is that some of the prose was a bit awkward. Sometimes, the story told me what I wanted shown. This worked occasionally, as it complemented the book's spare style; other times, though, it kept me from really seeing and feeling the action and emotions.Overall, an out-of-this-world read!...more

title: The Last Illusion
author: Khakpour, Porochista*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this book in two days while at Ucross, an artists' residency in beautiful northeast Wyoming. This was the perfect setting to read this novel beI read this book in two days while at Ucross, an artists' residency in beautiful northeast Wyoming. This was the perfect setting to read this novel because, 1. The author may have written parts of it in the very same studio I was reading/writing in, which felt magical and impossible-possible in a way that echoed the book's magical yet realistic tone and premise. And, 2. Because I had hours to do with what I wanted, and what I wanted was to write for a couple of hours, and then read for a couple of hours, write and then read, until bedtime. Ah, bliss!I fell into this book immediately and I loved Zal, the man who was raised as a bird by his uncaring mother. Khakpour's prose is exuberant and free-wheeling and so fuck-you-I-am-writing-this-nutty-paragraph-and-you-will-giggle-with-delight. It's fearless in this way that I admire greatly. It's also an engaging read--the first day I read 150 pages in a sitting and loved being absorbed in this imaginative world.I was less enamored with the magician, Silber, and that subplot--it felt less immediate and more...designed?...compared to the other parts of the novel; that might be hard to avoid, since Silber himself is a pretty contrived human, speaking in silly magician jargon and whatnot. It's all very fun to read, but it didn't move me in the way that the book's other parts did. The ending didn't quite land for me either, though it never stopped being compelling. I was moved and taken with the book overall. I want everyone to read it so we can discuss!...more

title: Zeroville
author: Erickson, Steve
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Strange, original, beguiling, addictive, problematic. I really liked this a whole lot more than I expected I would. I don't really care for movies--I Strange, original, beguiling, addictive, problematic. I really liked this a whole lot more than I expected I would. I don't really care for movies--I am one of the Angelenos Erickson describes in the novel who doesn't know a thing about cinema--and yet, and yet, this book worked its magic on me. I want to re-read it, to see how its structure works, and to understand how the echoes and motifs work, to make sense of Vikar's quest and notions of fathers and God. I liked how the book felt spliced together, how the time jumps worked, and how Erickson translated film into prose. The ending was crazy. I am pretty sure I put the book down and said, "What. The. Fuck." And then I rolled over, fell asleep, and some WTF-worthy dreams. Oh and the blow jobs! This book was almost ruined for me because of all the ladies who loved to give blow jobs-I mean, really? But then a teenage girl schools two adult men on their stupid masturbatory discussion of some sausage fest movie, and I loved the book anew....more

review: I can't decide what I think of this. I may give it another star tomorrow, in a year, a decade. I loved the structure and the unexpected, unresolved enI can't decide what I think of this. I may give it another star tomorrow, in a year, a decade. I loved the structure and the unexpected, unresolved endings to so many of these. Other times, though, I felt like the characters were quite thin, or that whole interactions were merely set-ups for a particular joke. Moore suffers from having an army of copycats, so that her unique voice sounds weirdly stale at times; it's too often imitated, which of course is not her fault. There is a bitterness to this collection that I found off-putting and also marvelous, in equal parts. It confused me, this one. Maybe that's a good thing? Ah, Lorrie Moore, what should I do?Also: This book was slightly wider than a traditional hardcover and it really bothered me! Take note, Knopf, take note....more

title: My Salinger Year
author: Rakoff, Joanna*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Vivid, precise, utterly absorbing. I was reading this as I made my son scrambled eggs this morning...I could not tear myself away. I loved the descripVivid, precise, utterly absorbing. I was reading this as I made my son scrambled eggs this morning...I could not tear myself away. I loved the descriptions of the venerable agency's refusal to enter the digital age; I loved Joanna's vulnerability and youth; I love the descriptions of New York in the 1990s; I loved her awful, fake-Communist, arrogant boyfriend; I love imagining a boss smoking cigarettes in her large office; I love the way Salinger is at the edges of Joanna's story, and also central to it in this very sly and meaningful way. It made me want to revisit his work.An assured, thoughtful, fun and touching read....more

review: I think this was a 4.5 star book for me but I am rounding up because at times the language was so genius, the syntax so new and startling, that I feltI think this was a 4.5 star book for me but I am rounding up because at times the language was so genius, the syntax so new and startling, that I felt I was reading something truly brilliant. This book reminded me a bit of George Saunders' work; something about the plural first person had a naive quality, a we're-maybe-only-fooling-ourselves-but-we-need-to-in-order-to-carry-on that reminded me of his stories and voice.I loved the point of view...god, it's so problematic in the best way! I loved wondering about how this book was structured, how the information was discovered and/or invented, and about what wasn't in the text. It demands re-reading for sure. I'd love to teach it someday. I also loved the world-building--B-Mor and the counties and all that jazz.The distance the narrative demands is what makes the book so fascinating but the lack of access to Fan's consciousness also frustrated me at times. I also felt disappointed that so much wasn't resolved plot-wise by the end. The picaresque quality to the tale also wasn't to my taste...I just don't prefer that kind of story, with characters meeting one stranger after another, etc. Overall, this is a unique and masterful novel! ...more

title: Friendship

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this book in a day and a half while at my in-laws' for Christmas. After feeling so disconnected from reading I was able to fall into three absoI read this book in a day and a half while at my in-laws' for Christmas. After feeling so disconnected from reading I was able to fall into three absorbing novels while on this trip--hallelujah! Emily Gould's Friendship was one of these novels.Gould's novel is a fun, funny, engaging and surprising read. I felt invested in the lives of Bev and Amy, even when I didn't like them. I really liked the novel's attention to money, or the lack of money, in the lives of these middle class (or affluent) white women. I came into this book knowing nothing, and I found the detours in the plot wonderfully unexpected. It was interesting to me how this book adhered to a normative plot about young women, and how it didn't. There was some darkness here, a little weirdness, just at the edge, that I liked a lot. Occasionally the prose felt a touch generic, and I wished the writing and the scenes felt more particular and specific. But, again, it was the perfect holiday read. Ah, to be holed up with a book! ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I zipped through two-thirds of this book in a day, and I really liked the assured, graceful prose. Sometimes the book was masterful--engaging, smart, I zipped through two-thirds of this book in a day, and I really liked the assured, graceful prose. Sometimes the book was masterful--engaging, smart, moving, thoughtful. Other times, though, it felt like Adichie lost the plot and the story felt meandering and unfocused. Some of the dialogue was stilted and a touch didactic--sometimes the group scenes reminded me of Atlas Shrugged (but never that bad!). Sometimes, all but the two main characters were a little too satirically drawn for my taste. But, overall, I liked this one, and I came away appreciating its messiness, even if it didn't always work. I like a writer who just goes for it....more

review: This book is so beautiful. Although I loved the prose and the setting from the beginning, its episodic style was hard to get into. I had a difficulty This book is so beautiful. Although I loved the prose and the setting from the beginning, its episodic style was hard to get into. I had a difficulty remembering who characters were, and sometimes the summarized nature made it hard to really feel invested in the heroine's, Cressida's, conflicts. But, but! I am so glad I stuck with this. This novel accrues meaning and beauty and heft as it goes on, and it's devastating. I was so moved by the ending, my throat heavy, my eyes tearing up...Huneven depicts with such elegance the thrills and pain of love and longing. It's an incredible book about adultery, from the point of view of the "other woman"...Also, it made me want to go hiking. HIKING. If you know me, then you know that's a literary miracle!I love Michelle Huneven's work....more

title: The Vacationers

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a wonderfully pleasurable read. I love Emma's prose--it's buttery and smooth and precise and funny and fluid and fun to read. I loved beiThis book is a wonderfully pleasurable read. I love Emma's prose--it's buttery and smooth and precise and funny and fluid and fun to read. I loved being in Mallorca, in this magical house with its magical swimming pool, eating such magical food and watching the Post family in all their functional dysfunction. (Ha, I was in California eating leftover Chinese food but I was somewhere else entirely!) I really liked Bobby Post's girlfriend, Carmen; she is so different from the other bookish folks, so misunderstood and isolated, and Franny's distaste of her and her gym-life was funny and sad, and also believable. I liked the tensions of the the book overall; there is an inevitable pressure exerted on a narrative when people with issues are packed into a space together. Also: I was very proud that this book had some sexy bits--a nice development in the ouevre of Ms. Straub!Sometimes I wanted the narrative drive of the novel to be stronger--the premise is rich but occasionally the book captured the wandering timeless quality of vacationing a bit too well. Don't misunderstand: the novel was never ever boring, but sometimes I felt a lack of tautness, a diffusion of energy. I also wanted a bit more about how and why a particular character came to an important decision (I am being vague so as not to give any of the plot away!)The final scene took my breath away and made me love this book....more

review: This is an enjoyable, thoughtful book, one that made me laugh and nod in acknowledgment (the description of watching a toddler poop is terrific and toThis is an enjoyable, thoughtful book, one that made me laugh and nod in acknowledgment (the description of watching a toddler poop is terrific and totally accurate! Ha.), and gnash my teeth at the characters' (believable) dysfunction. Fierro has created fallible, complex and even frustrating characters. (Lordy, am I glad I don't raise my kid in Brooklyn! Those parents are cuh-razy!) I loved the shifting POV and the way it allowed me access into the private, conflicted minds of these people. I especially loved the nanny, Tenzin, and the stay-at-home dad, Rip. I thought Nicole was the most well-rounded of the group in some ways, and Fierro wonderfully evokes her anxieties, understandable and far fetched; I really felt for her.Sometimes I wondered how this group of people could ever keep a moms/dad group together since they didn't seem to like each other much. I also found a few references to products--like one character's brand of jeans--distracting and unnecessary. That character, Allie, was distinctly drawn, particularly her struggles to be a parent and an artist, but her art career itself was convoluted to me, and I couldn't get a clear, real sense of what kind of photography she did.Other than that, I was totally riveted by this one...!...more

review: I finished this ages ago and forgot to rate it. This book really did a number on me. Maybe it's that certain scenes took place around the corner from I finished this ages ago and forgot to rate it. This book really did a number on me. Maybe it's that certain scenes took place around the corner from where I grew up, or that a scene takes place at King's Road (I could eat their purple cabbage salad every day!), or that the prose is so graceful, eloquent, and risky in its leaps for profundity and beauty. Or maybe it's because I loved the main character, Beau, the overweight and tragic Hollywood agent, or because I loved the first person omniscient POV. This novel is a little too long, and a few of transitions were a bit confusing, but I loved the book nonetheless, for its heart, its ambition, its LA-ness. It's wonderful. ...more

title: A Tale for the Time Being
author: Ozeki, Ruth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved Nao's voice and story and was amazed by how the narrative branched out and out and out as it went on...much like some of the quantum physics sI loved Nao's voice and story and was amazed by how the narrative branched out and out and out as it went on...much like some of the quantum physics stuff discussed in the book! I was in love with Nao's great grandmother and moved by the letters written by her great uncle. I found myself emotionally engaged throughout, which seems a wonderful feat considering the heady structure of the narrative. I was less interested in the sections with Ruth; those felt very wooden to me, and I was continually surprised by the use of the third person--it just kept feeling contrived and somehow wrong: they made me conscious of the writing in a mechanical way, almost as if I was teaching/reading an early draft. These sections felt like life, but their verisimilitude also leached the drama from the narrative, particularly in comparison to Nao's section. Ozeki is a masterful writer, and I sense a desire on her part to have Ruth's chapters feel workaday, to bring into question our notions of time/drama in fiction. Still, I was less engaged, less amazed in these chapters. I love the unresolved quality of the story, and how much it made me think about time, consciousness, writing, the internet.(A silly aside: though I wasn't rooting for cat Pesto's demise, I did feel annoyed early on by all the cats in the book. I get enough cat shit on the internet! I wish they wouldn't lulz in my literature too!)Overall, I loved this book and I can't wait to discuss it with friends. Read it and tell me what you think!...more

review: I read Holt's debut quickly because it was an easy and pleasurable read. The last page is great--haunting, with a touch of childish innocence that is I read Holt's debut quickly because it was an easy and pleasurable read. The last page is great--haunting, with a touch of childish innocence that is also wise, and it echoes the book's mournful nostalgia perfectly. Although I liked reading about 1990s Russia, I did in the middle of the novel feel like some scenes got a bit top travelogue for my taste, especially since they felt like a device to prologue/delay the revelation of plot. I saw the twist coming from very early on, and in a way I wish there was a more intricate secret buried in the story...though Holt handles the final twenty pages wonderfully, and I love their ambiguity. Overall, I enjoyed this graceful and compelling narrative!...more

The structure of each section was fun to read but also almost always the same, which made for a less surprising book than it otherwise could have been.) I really loved Mitchell, I found Leonard intriguing but perhaps a touch one-note, and our heroine Madeleine was a dolt with nice legs. She was a fan of Jane Austen, et al, but she didn't seem particularly bright--not nearly as bright as an Austen heroine. And not emotionally astute either! But she also was a believable human being to me, and I cared about her. I love reading about college life and love, and though there were times when I wished the author's treatment of both had been less surfacey, I still delighted in the novel, with its graceful turns of phrase and zippiness of paragraphs.  ...more

title: Where'd You Go, Bernadette
author: Semple, Maria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a truly pleasurable read. I zipped through it in a few days, and whenever I wasn't reading it, I wanted to be doing so. I laughed and I laughThis was a truly pleasurable read. I zipped through it in a few days, and whenever I wasn't reading it, I wanted to be doing so. I laughed and I laughed as I read this, but I also found it be quite moving and thought-provoking. I really disliked Bernadette in the first 20 pages, in particular for how she addressed her "virtual assistant" in India, and at first I thought, "Oh God. Private school white people! I hate private school white people!" (Sorry--must be my LAUSD defensiveness and pride growling to life!) But that antipathy faded as these people's lives came into focus and depth. I loved Bernadette by the end, and I loved her most for her flaws.I adored the epistolary format of the novel, and I was so interested in how we came to understand Bernadette and her family by these various sources--their identities were collaged together in such a readable and fascinating way. I was actually going to give this book 5 stars, but the ending didn't really land. The epistolary structure mostly ended and the straightforward 1st person narrative was less memorable. The twists and turns for the plot were a touch too unbelievable. Still a good read, just not as amazing for me as before. I do recommend this very highly, if only for Bernadette's rants about tattoos and Seattle in general. So delicious!...more

review: This book is fun and snarly, with scenes as taut as a cheerleader's hamstrings. I loved the descriptions of the body, its power and skill and machinerThis book is fun and snarly, with scenes as taut as a cheerleader's hamstrings. I loved the descriptions of the body, its power and skill and machinery, as well as the way female intimacy was depicted: it's not every female relationship, but it's certainly one kind: competitive and scary and f-ed up, but also intimate and tender and physical. All of that at once.The middle of the book really sagged for me, but I loved the opening and the end. Weirdly, the mystery felt unimportant. At times this was a 4-star book, and others times a 3. I am rounding up for lines like this:"How is it that other girls' panties are always so much more interesting than your own."Rah! Rah! Rah! Don't sneer at me when I tell you I am reading a novel about cheerleaders. You. Have. No. Idea. What. This. Means....more

review: A readable, smoothly told book with a great hook. The thing is, it felt like the hook--that the earth is slowing--is all it had. The actual conflict, A readable, smoothly told book with a great hook. The thing is, it felt like the hook--that the earth is slowing--is all it had. The actual conflict, the drama with the family, the narrator's love for the boy at school, felt thin, overly-familiar. It also felt a bit too easy for me: I wanted things to be a bit more complicated, maybe in terms of the retrospective presence, or with the structure and language. There are some stunning moments and great descriptions, and there were a couple of moments at the end that made me feel just pure grief, but overall: I wasn't totally invested in this story and its characters. Also, the writing, though often lovely, felt a bit too placid, like it had taken a valium or something. Very flat. Maybe that's what everyone else is calling "haunting"?...more

title: The Year of the Beasts
author: Castellucci, Cecil*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is more a 4.5 star book for me, but I'm rounding up because 1) The prose-graphic novel hybrid genre was unique and pretty dang spectacular aThis book is more a 4.5 star book for me, but I'm rounding up because 1) The prose-graphic novel hybrid genre was unique and pretty dang spectacular and worth an extra point or two, and 2) Cecil is my homegirl, and 3) Why not? Sometimes this book did indeed amaze me.I really liked the sad, dark places this book went--not only in the events, but the feelings of its main character, Tess. She has some pretty unsavory thoughts about her sister; they are selfish thoughts: immature and complicated and utterly, utterly true. This made for a complicating reading experience that I think readers--young and fully-grown--can get into. I also liked the fairy tale old-timey quality to it: it's a contemporary world, but there are old-school carnivals and fluttery feelings about boys, and doll houses, and make-out sessions in the woods, and melting ice cream. The tone felt in-tune with the graphic sections, which were beautifully drawn and perfectly mysterious, and sometimes so dark and scary I felt ill (in a good way). There is an other-worldly quality to both sections; they're otherworldly in different ways, but they complemented each other.The loneliness in this book was my favorite part. It's a deeply lonely book--it captures that feeling with a PING! There were a few sentences I desperately wanted to rephrase to be cleaner and more fluid. Overall, I liked the prose (trademark Castellucci!), but sometimes it felt less polished than it could have been. And I wished the graphic sections and the prose sections interacted in a more surprising and clever way at the end. I think my expectations were way, way too high, but whatever, it's worth saying: I thought they were going to seriously collide, and they didn't exactly.This is the strongest Cecil Castellucci book I've read so far: it's lovely, strange, unique, sensitive, sad, insightful, heartfelt. I recommend it! ...more

title: The Middlesteins
author: Attenberg, Jami*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was structured in an unexpected and pleasing way, skipping across decades and perspectives to keep me entranced and entertained. I loved theThis book was structured in an unexpected and pleasing way, skipping across decades and perspectives to keep me entranced and entertained. I loved the humor, the deft compression of time, the sharp observations of contemporary east coast America (most of takes place in the Chicago-area but there was a section about New York that amazed and amazed), and the way we came to know each member of the Middlestein clan. It was also incredibly moving at the end: there were some really beautiful moments that were deeply compassionate. I was also impressed that Attenberg took on food addiction as a topic and as a character trait--it felt fresh, and also believable, and complicated. Food is beautiful, food is love, food is dangerous, food is nothing, food is everything. Occasionally, the omniscience stuck out to me: not that it didn't work, just that I always noticed it, and kind of in a strange, craft-thinking distracting way. Also, I wanted MORE. I wish this novel had been 100 pages longer...I think we could have gone deeper with these characters, and seen more of their present conflicts. More! More! More! To use some food metaphors: This novel was a tasty meal with complex favors that wasn't quite hearty enough for this diner/reader. But maybe I need to practice portion control? (Thank you, goodnight!)...more

title: Laura Lamont's Life in Pictures
author: Straub, Emma*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't really judge this novel objectively as the author is a dear friend of mine. We were in our nonfiction workshop at Oberlin together! I attendedI can't really judge this novel objectively as the author is a dear friend of mine. We were in our nonfiction workshop at Oberlin together! I attended her Russian Nightclub house party! We've double-dated! Emma and I got reacquainted a few years ago, after college, and found we had much in common, particularly that were both (still) writers and lovers of books. I have been SO excited to read her debut novel! It didn't disappoint.I love the prose here: it's as milky and winsome as the book's namesake, Laura Lamont. For a week I neglected my child to get back to this story of a woman's life as she goes from Wisconsin playhouse sister to Hollywood movie star. For a novel that's not particularly plot-driven, it's very hard to put down! I really admired the compassion Emma had for her characters, and the ways she made me feel connected to Laura (nee Elsa). I also loved learning about the studio system of Hollywood; despite being an L.A. native, I know nothing about movies and cinema history. I also liked the way this book compressed time. Wooh, I love this kind book: alighting on moments that matter, gliding over years. Again and again this book jumped forward in time, starting a new chapter with this terrific authority that set the scene, the time, the tone, in my mind. I L-O-V-E-D that. I wish I could do that! I was very much interested in how juvenile and naive Laura seemed at times, and how in control her second husband Irving was. I thought that relationship was going to implode at some point, that Laura would crave independence. That it didn't intrigued me, and had me thinking a lot about Laura's conception of self, and my own conception of her and her self. She was certainly a product of her era. Also: the ending was lovely, just lovely.There were a couple of weird geography things (sorry, Emma!!!). For instance, I don't think Los Feliz was considered the eastside in the 1930s, though I might be wrong. Overall, I wish LA had been a larger character, as much as Wisconsin was. I didn't often *feel* place in this book. I also felt like there was too much attention paid to her sisters and her traumatic past. It sometimes felt repetitive to me. I also longed for more social complications in the book, perhaps with her black housekeeper Harriet, or with her kids, when the 1960s and 1970s hit full swing. But I don't think that was Emma's project here--she's after an intimate view, not a Forrest Gumpian one--and I can accept that.A fun and thoughtful book! ...more

title: Pulphead
author: Sullivan, John Jeremiah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't fall in love with this book like everyone else I know. I enjoyed many of these essays, particularly the one about him as a writer's assistantI didn't fall in love with this book like everyone else I know. I enjoyed many of these essays, particularly the one about him as a writer's assistant. Sullivan can surely craft a sentence, and he's no doubt a bright MoFo. The thing is, for me, many of these pieces felt overly mannered, like intellectual experiments in voice. His narrative "I" didn't always feel true to me, whatever that means. I was engaged with these pieces on a brainiac level, but I was never inside of them, never truly invested. I don't read many (any) essay collections, so who knows what I expected/wanted. I just know that I'm marking this as "read" even though there are a few I haven't read and don't feel like reading. Side note: I believe Sullivan's work is sometimes compared to the nonfiction David Foster Wallace. And the novel Skippy Dies was compared to DFW's fiction. Neither book I loved (I actively disliked Skippy Dies). This makes me think I won't enjoy Infinite Jest, or Consider the Lobster, when I finally get to them...and now I am not rushing to get to them. I can't stand the DFW hagiography these days, so I'm just stepping out of the discussion for now. Thoughts? ...more

She's well reaI really don't know what to rate this, so I won't. Margot Livesey was my writing teacher--and one I am incredibly grateful to have had. She's well read, so compassionate, insightful, and her accent makes even the harshest criticism go down like molasses. I've enjoyed keeping up with her since graduation, and her last book--The House on Fortune Street--was incredible. I highly recommend it to anyone new to the Livesey ouevre. I'd definitely start with that one. Gemma Hardy kept my attention and I loved comparing it to Jane Eyre, which I re-read not too long ago. It was interesting to note how Gemma's story echoes Jane's, and where it diverges. I liked the prose a lot--so easy to fall into, and smooth, the rhythm like a big duvet I wanted to wrap myself up in. Gemma is spirited like Jane, and unloved, like Jane, and I was interested in her plight from unloved orphan to self-possessed young woman. I will read any story about orphans, governesses, and the like. Make it take place in remote Scotland, and I'm yours forever.Something is keeping me from really liking this book, though, and I'm having trouble articulating what that is. The echoes of Jane Eyre kept me reading, but oddly, they also made the story predictable, because I was just waiting for the next similarity to arise. (Mr. Rochester stand-in? Check. Etc etc.). In general, the plot seemed to lack a certain, I don't know, verve or something. What made Jane Eyre seem transgressive and new isn't present in Livesey's version; I don't know what that special something is though.I also would've loved for this to have taken place in the modern era, rather than the 1950s-1960s, which at times felt as antiquated as the 19th century that Bronte wrote about. I wondered what Jane might do in the era of crop tops and internet dating. Just a thought...I enjoyed this book, but I wanted to enjoy it more. In the end, Margot Livesey can write a beautiful paragraph and loveable characters. This one, though, didn't quite hit the spot like some of her other novels...(God this is such a dumb . I haven't slept in 8 months, okay?!)...more

title: Solve Your Child's Sleep Problems
author: Ferber, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, I read what I needed to at this stage in the game (4 months into parenting), and I will go back as needed, as The Bean's habits change.Ferber ofteSo, I read what I needed to at this stage in the game (4 months into parenting), and I will go back as needed, as The Bean's habits change.Ferber often gets a bad rap, and most people who know of him think he's all/just about letting your kid cry it out. The book is actually more nuanced and compassionate than that, and I found his discussion of sleep cycles pretty illuminating and helpful. My baby can fall asleep without nursing, which is great, since it not only means Daddy can be The Bedtime Master, but also that my baby knows how to go to bed on his own, self-soothing and all that--this is a skill he will need for life! (I should say that I figured out he could fall asleep without nursing pretty much by accident; he just fell asleep one day, on his own, and it was clear he didn't need my boob as much as I'd assumed.) Ferber helped us realize that Dixon doesn't need to eat at 10 pm, 3 hours after he's fallen asleep. It's more likely that he's entering a new sleep cycle, and that he can figure out how to get back to bed on his own. On the first night after reading this book, he cried at 10:15, and my husband and I waited, breathless, on the couch, to see what would happen if we didn't run to his rescue. 20 seconds later, he was fast asleep and didn't wake up again until 1:30! He hasn't woken at 10-ish since. Now we're trying to figure out which night-time feeding is truly necessary--for his belly, for his soul--and which one(s) can be eliminated. It's a bit touch and go, but we're learning. I'm trying to balance some of Ferber's ideas with my own instincts. I'm hoping Ferber can next help me get some more naps into my kid! When baby sleeps more during the day, the nights are far more peaceful.This is an informative read for anyone with young children who is struggling to figure out nap schedules, bedtime routines, night feedings, and so on. Don't be afraid to Ferberize! (God, that word--it's scary, right?)And, sometimes it's okay if a baby cries. My mom said I used to cry for 2-3 minutes every night before bed, and then slept 12 hours straight. I needed that little cry, to expend some energy before my nightly coma. Don't knock it! Also, don't let your kid cry for hours while you surf the internet. Jesus....more

review: I read most of this book in the few days before I went into labor, and then took a few days off to, you know, have a baby. So the momentum of the storI read most of this book in the few days before I went into labor, and then took a few days off to, you know, have a baby. So the momentum of the story/mystery was slowed a bit, taking away from the intensity of my reading experience. Still, until I went into labor I could not put this novel down, and the fact that I finished the book during the first days of nursing speaks to its pull. The Likeness is certainly far-fetched, premise-wise, but that was fine with me. I totally dug The Secret History vibe of this close-knit group of graduate students, as well as the Gothic tone of the big ancestral home they live in. I am so smitten with the idea of going undercover...what drama, what danger! French's writing is, as with In the Woods, lovely. Can't wait to read the next in the series!...more

title: In the Woods        (Dublin Murder Squad, #1)
author: French, Tana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the first police procedural I've ever read, though I enjoy them on television and the big screen, so it's hard for me to critique this book. IThis is the first police procedural I've ever read, though I enjoy them on television and the big screen, so it's hard for me to critique this book. I mean, what do I know? I loved French's prose--it's rich and its rhythms and imagery were pleasing--and I loved how readable the book was. I thought Detectives Rob and Cassie's relationship--their friendship and working relationship--was nicely depicted and complex. I liked that Rob, the narrator, was such a dolt, emotionally-speaking. It made him human and real to me. My main beef with the novel is that the ending is a bit of a let-down. I have a hard time when questions get answered via a detective's smooth operations in the interrogation room. Does ANYONE fall for good cop/bad cop anymore? More than that, though, our narrator becomes stupid at the end. He doesn't see what's coming, and I didn't buy his denial. I mean, even I--reader of quiet literary fiction--saw what was coming! His foolishness rendered him a far less interesting character than he had been for previous 385 pages. Things didn't feel quite true.Still, I enjoyed this novel, and I look forward to reading more of French's delicious prose. Check out these lines:"I wish I could tell you how an interrogation can have its own beauty, shining and cruel as that of a bullfight; how in defiance of the crudest topic or the most moronic suspect it keeps inviolate its own taut, honed grace, its own irresistible and blood-stirring rhythms; how the great pairs of detectives know each other's every thought as surely as lifelong ballet partners in a pas de deux..."...more

I'm not sure what I think of the whole RIE approach, but I'm certainly curious.Right now, I like the idea of doing a 'tapas' approach to parenting: a taste of this, a taste of that. Yum, tapas...!***There's some practical and common sense advice in this book. I like the idea of giving your child the space and freedom to do things on their own, to not help them too much as they reach for the toy, etc. etc. And, of course, we should talk to our children as we change their clothes and whatnot! Sometimes, though, the tone rubbed me the wrong way. It felt a bit superior, sort of "This, little parent, is the best, the only way to raise a child! How dare someone go another route!" All parenting-philosophies can be like this, I suppose. Again, I like the idea of doing what works, and using different aspects of different parenting approaches, to meet my and my child's needs. RIE feels a little restrictive for me....more

review: The coy jacket copy and the retitling of this book from The Other Hand to Little Bee does this book a disservice. It adds an aura of cheesy and sentimThe coy jacket copy and the retitling of this book from The Other Hand to Little Bee does this book a disservice. It adds an aura of cheesy and sentimentality to a novel that is often quite brutal and unflinchingly so. There were times when I was taken by both the voices of British Sarah and Nigerian Little Bee--I loved Bee's humor and Sarah's brittle observations--and overall, this was a smooth read with a lot of great, surprising moments. Sometimes, though, the novel's writing was overwrought and cheesy. It felt like it was trying to push BIG FEELINGS on me. Little Bee's memories of her upbringing often had me rolling my eyes, and I had the hardest time with Sarah's son Batman. Oof--that felt a little heavy handed! I also didn't believe Sarah's lover Lawrence; I didn't quite understand his anger or his antagonism, and I found his role in the story strangely device-y. ...more

I just finished re-reading the book (the pAnna Solomon is a dear friend of mine and I had the pleasure of reading and critiquing early draft of this. I just finished re-reading the book (the published version!) this afternoon, and I am a bit breathless...it's such a beautiful, brave, compelling book about such flawed and complicated people who feel so incredibly real. I love the evocation of weather in this novel (so hot and dry! And then, wow, so c-c-cold!), and the way Solomon makes this particular moment of history come alive on the page. I love how stubborn and delusional and selfish and insecure and true Minna is. She is full of a longing that is real and meaningful and burdensome: oh, to be 16 and a mail order bride in The Middle of Nowhere, South Dakota! I love the Indians who are often talked about and wondered about, but never appear. I love how well Solomon captures sex without desire--how repugnant it is! And I love, love, love the language of this book, and the deft ways it compresses time and switches back and forth to different events within a few pages. The final chapter is my favorite for the way it just takes charge, and lets time fast forward. This is a great first novel, and so hard to put down. Read it! I'm proud to be Anna's friend and writing buddy!...more

title: Skippy Dies
author: Murray, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book had some moments of real beauty and genius, and certainly there were some funny scenes. I liked Skippy, Howard and Ruprecht a lot, and I resThis book had some moments of real beauty and genius, and certainly there were some funny scenes. I liked Skippy, Howard and Ruprecht a lot, and I respected the formal risks the narrative took. Overall, though, the book moved at such a glacial pace. The events that occurred unfolded so very, very slowly, that it was hard to enjoy even the few surprises in the plot. I quickly fatigued of the jokey sections with the kids--though often funny, they were the same scene, over and over again. Some of the minor characters, in particular the acting principal, were so flat that their scenes also became repetitive, and thus, boring. I either felt like I was a step ahead of the storyline, understanding what the scene wanted to do or establish, and just waiting for that to happen in the scene itself. Or, I was very confused--a lot of the chapters open in a such a close third person perspective that it's unclear what the hell is going on--since each chapter switches to one of the many, many characters. There was one chapter early on with a ton of sound effects and three characters I hadn't met before, and the work it took to figure out what was happening was just too taxing for little old me. Ay!Also, and this isn't bad or good, just an observation: A lot of the interactions between characters felt particularly visual. Like, it would have been dramatic and funny on screen, but that it took too many steps to make it clear on the page. I felt like I was doing a lot of translating, if that makes any sense...As I said, there's some great material here, but I was ultimately disappointed,and I don't quite understand the craze for this book. ...more

title: Silver Sparrow
author: Jones, Tayari*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At times I felt this was a solid 3 star book, and other times I felt it was totally 4, with moments of dazzling 5-starness. In the end, I've decided tAt times I felt this was a solid 3 star book, and other times I felt it was totally 4, with moments of dazzling 5-starness. In the end, I've decided to round up and give it a 4, as I've found myself thinking about its characters and their pain since I finished it yesterday. Firstly, this was an enormously pleasant book to read. The prose and voices of the two first-person narrations are smooth and engaging, and I found myself absorbed by the story without trouble. Often, I'd read 20, 40 pages without even realizing it. As someone who is about to have a baby, and in need of a distraction, this was fabulous!I loved reading about Atlanta in the late-seventies and eighties, and I found Dana and Chaurisse to be compelling characters. What connects them--their father--gives this book power and injects the novel with suspense. But, really, it was the little stuff that I liked best: descriptions of their (very different) mothers, the beauty parlor Chaurisse's mom runs out of her house, Dana's relationship with her boyfriend who won't acknowledge her in public, stories of the world before they were born...it's all so rich and vivid, and compelling. In Dana's first half, I felt like the book was a little too obsessed with the issue of her father's bigamy. I know, I know: that's the book's subject, but it felt like her section didn't have a center, didn't have anything pulling it forward beyond premise and theme. Although I enjoyed reading her part, I felt it was too on-the-nose at times, and that it lacked some narrative oomph. It felt a little too easy, or on-the-surface,or just too neat--I'm not sure what the problem was, for me. I loved moving to Chaurisse's section, to get her side of the story, and there was a nice narrative zing! each time Dana came on the scene. At times here, though, there was an odd lack of drama because we, as readers, had the information that Chaurisse didn't, and getting to the inevitable felt a bit tedious. That's too harsh actually, as the book itself is never tedious--it's always fun to read, and I was always emotionally connected. I just kept wondering, if there might have been a better way to structure the narrative, to get the most of out of its premise and plot.I loved, LOVED, the epilogue. It was fucking sad, and I felt like Jones just let things suck for her characters--because that was the only true ending. This was satisfying and moving, and it's what kept me thinking about the book after I'd finished it....more

title: The French Lieutenant’s Woman
author: Fowles, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was enamored with and intrigued by the omniscient third person narrator of this novel, who let me into the Victorian drama of Charles, Sarah, and ErI was enamored with and intrigued by the omniscient third person narrator of this novel, who let me into the Victorian drama of Charles, Sarah, and Ernestina (love that name) only to yank me out of it to remind me that he and I were not of the 19th century, but of the 20th (him) and the 21st (me). So cool! This style of narration was a perfect, modern example of an authorial, knowing narrator who is wholly present in the story, even if he's not a physical character (unless he is, momentarily...but that was just a bit of PoMo cleverness). This point of view allowed the narrator to step back and analyze the characters' actions in the context of the time they existed, and to compare their era with that of 1960s England (the narrator's time). That was great fun, and the book overall was an example of experimentation that can feel meaningful and useful, and not simply smart or strange for strange's sake.But, oh, dear lord, this book was so SLOW. There were times when I cursed its asides and its allusions that I did not understand. It's been a long time since a novel made me feel stupid. It seems Mr. Fowles and I live in entirely different worlds, where our points of references barely intersect. I also had a hard time understanding Sarah's motivations, and at the end of the book I felt totally lost with regards to the characters' emotional arcs. I refuse to blame this on myself, for I am a careful reader. Also, I couldn't understand Sarah's attraction or love for Charles. He seemed like a wet blanket, whereas she was mysterious and sensuous and even I wanted to see her with her hair down. Fowles successfully created desire for his female character, but I think he failed when it came to making his male character as magnetic and desirable.At times I found this book truly amazing and admirable and utterly original. At other times I wanted to smack it around and tell it to just get interesting. What to rate such a novel?...more

title: Mothers and Daughters
author: Meadows, Rae*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book--about the lives of three generations of women--was such a smooth, lovely read. At first I worried it was a bit too easy, a bit too smooth, This book--about the lives of three generations of women--was such a smooth, lovely read. At first I worried it was a bit too easy, a bit too smooth, but as it went on there were passages that really made me pause to think, to revel in the beauty of the prose and the cleverness of its intertwining tales. I liked reading about motherhood and what's passed down from mother to daughter. This was a book I kept reading, especially when I should have been writing or washing dishes or paying attention to my dog. It was a wonderful morning-book--it seemed to match the warm light of my apartment as the day's just getting started...Sometimes I felt like the chapters were a bit too short. Each one focuses on one of three women, and I'd have to switch to the next character right as I was getting into the current one. I would have like more sustained attention on each character, I suppose. Also, occasionally, Violet's sections--which are historical--were so colorful that they felt almost too cinematic, if that makes any sense. I did like how Meadows focused on one day in the life of Sam, the contemporary character, a mother of infant Ella, and then, for Sam's mother, Iris, the chapters covered a few days (which took place a year before the Sam sections). Violet's sections--from the early 1900s (or late 1800s?)--cover quite a bit more time. These shifts in time were seamless, and I didn't even notice the differences until near the end of the book. Some of Sam's sections reminded me of Mrs Dalloway (because of Sam's 1-day, and the crises therein), and the whole book had a similar appeal that The Hours by Michael Cunningham does. It's fitting that Iris is reading Woolf (To The Lighthouse), in her sections...Oh, and I love the evocation of setting in the novel, from Madison, WI to Sansibel Island, Florida, to the early tenements of New York City. It was all wonderfully detailed and rich.Overall, this a pleasurable and thoughtful novel. (If only the cover weren't so goddamned PINK and CHEESY! I hope that doesn't detract readers like me--ladies who don't go for butterfly wings. Grrr...)...more

title: Ina May's Guide to Childbirth
author: Gaskin, Ina May
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was a bucket full of awesome. I mean, yes, Ina May is the head midwife on the cultishly-named birthing commune The Farm. And, yes, I believeThis book was a bucket full of awesome. I mean, yes, Ina May is the head midwife on the cultishly-named birthing commune The Farm. And, yes, I believe she wears her hair parted in the middle (perhaps even in two braids!). But don't let that scare you off. I re-read the beginning part this week to get pumped for my upcoming labor; these are just first-person, candid accounts of women who have given birth on The Farm. Reading these beautiful, well-detailed and honest stories really got me feeling excited and positive about labor. The rest of the book didn't offer much new information for me since I've read a few other birthing books and have taken a Bradley class, but I appreciated Gaskin's straightforward  of labor and midwifery v. hospital practices. I loved reading about orgasmic births (wowza!), and about the amazing talents of the punani, and I am taking her kissing-during-contractions tip with me to the hospital! (Also, the use of laughter and shaking of the pregnant woman's limbs was useful to remember, too.) I also liked reading about how birth went from upright to supine (depressing), and about the famous midwives of yore (uplifting).I recommend this book to all parents-to-be. Dude, even if you aren't even a smidgen hippie you can learn a lot from Ms. Gaskin and the women who work on The Farm; the statistics of their practice back up their knowledge and confidence in women and their bodies......more

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
author: Skloot, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was surprisingly enjoyable. I know everyone says it's enjoyable, but I was surprised considering its subject. I mean, cells? Um, sorry, but This book was surprisingly enjoyable. I know everyone says it's enjoyable, but I was surprised considering its subject. I mean, cells? Um, sorry, but ever since that school project where I made a cell out of hair gel, a grape and one of those plastic shells to display a baseball in, I haven't been much interested in the topic. But Skloot makes biology accessible to even the most ignorant among us (read: me), and I found myself wanting to get into a lab and explore these topics further! I learned a lot from this book, and felt really connected to Henrietta Lacks and her story. I was impressed by how easily Skloot wove together all this science history with the history of one woman and her family's struggles, as well as the legal, racial and socioeconomic issues therein. This is probably a 5-star book for others, but since I'm not a nonfiction junkie I just couldn't go all the way there. It's an informative, entertaining and often emotional read, just not my favorite of the year or anything. I did totally love all the stories about the nutty "scientific" practices of doctors in ye olden times. If anyone wants to get me a baby in a jar for my birthday, please do....more

review: I loved being in 1930s New York--the dark apartments with their soggy stairs; the courtyards filled with Italian children; the sweatshop the narrator I loved being in 1930s New York--the dark apartments with their soggy stairs; the courtyards filled with Italian children; the sweatshop the narrator briefly works in, cutting the threads off beautiful dresses. I enjoyed the realism of the story, and I found Harriet's child-like way with the world--after being in the hospital for so long--quite riveting, and surprising each time it came up.I didn't, however, like the more associative, stream of consciousness writing that was braided into the straightforward story. It just seemed like bad writing to me. Let me see if I can do a parody of it:Freedom. Death. Darkness. Light. To live. To--oh!Ha ha! It made me laugh, it made me skim. I couldn't get into it. I was glad for the drama of the story, and the quiet beauty of Harriet and John's love, which felt real and tender and delicious to me, and so of the era, and yet timeless, too. If not for that, I would have certainly stopped reading what is otherwise a strange and lovely book about independence, work, and recovery....more

review: Madeline McDonnell, the author of this gorgeous and beguiling little book, is one of my closest friends, and she's my writing buddy, so there's no wayMadeline McDonnell, the author of this gorgeous and beguiling little book, is one of my closest friends, and she's my writing buddy, so there's no way of being objective here. I've read earlier drafts of two of these stories, and the third I knew about, but had never read. I so delight in McDonnell's prose: in her sensual observations, her language play, her descriptions of sky, light, the body, the heart. These are three stories about three lost women. They are funny, surprising, weird, and sad stories, and each one took my breath away by its end. I am so honored to know Madeline, and to get to share my work with her, and to have her share her work with me.She has promised me the first draft of her novel by next spring, and I know it's going to melt my face off with its brilliance and beauty. I can't wait for the whole world to get it. In the meantime, read this gem of a book!...more

review: This isn't a perfect novel (it's a little long; it can be repetitive; occasionally the epistolary conceit shows its marionette strings), but it is whoThis isn't a perfect novel (it's a little long; it can be repetitive; occasionally the epistolary conceit shows its marionette strings), but it is wholly and deeply imagined, and it so rocked me. To read such a scary portrait of motherhood a few months before I myself am to have my first kid was somewhat of a mind fuck, but perhaps that's why I couldn't put the book down. I appreciated its darkness, even as it made me uncomfortable, and I loved its dark comedic tone as well as the very real pain of its narrator, Eva. Sometimes the darkness was oppressive and I had to take a break--but not for long, because the story was so readable. I appreciated the places Shriver was willing to go, and I admired the dexterity of her prose and how thoroughly and bravely she excavated this complicated narrator, flaws and all.From page 51 (of the paperback)--the narrator on her pregnancy:"Meanwhile, I came to regard my body in a new light. For the first time I apprehended the little mounds on my chest as teats for the suckling of young, and their physical resemblance to udders on cows or the swinging distentions on lactating hounds was suddenly unavoidable. Funny how even women forget what breasts are for.The cleft between my legs transformed as well. It lost a certain outrageousness, an obscenity, or achieved an obscenity of a different sort. The flaps seemed to open not to a narrow, snug dead end, but to something yawning. The passageway itself became a route to somewhere else, a real place, and not merely to a darkness of my mind. The twist of flesh in front took on a devious aspect, its inclusion overtly ulterior, a tempter, a sweetener for doing the species' heavy lifting, like the lollipops I once got at the dentist."...more

review: I am in such a reading rut, and have been since September or so. I got through Freedom, but it took almost a month, and since then, I haven't found a I am in such a reading rut, and have been since September or so. I got through Freedom, but it took almost a month, and since then, I haven't found a book that really captures my heart and mind, and makes me put down all other tasks so that I can read it. This book was recommended to me by a friend, and I purchased it without really even looking at it. There's some beautiful prose, but the premise was a little too unbelievable to me. A three-year-old girl gets taken from her home by the man who fixes the water heater, and then she moves through a series of strange characters, some of whom she stays with, some of whom simply cross her path. I just had trouble with this concept, and I wanted to feel more than disconcerted. Also, many of the characters speechify to little Sal, and I got bored of that pattern. I only got about 60 pages in, which perhaps isn't fair. I blame myself for not connecting with this book. I could see how another reader might fall in love. It's just not for me.And so I continue my reading rut. Ugh. ...more

review: I found this book to be at times entertaining, at times quite tedious. Sometimes the prose dazzled, sometimes it exhausted, a few times it left me undI found this book to be at times entertaining, at times quite tedious. Sometimes the prose dazzled, sometimes it exhausted, a few times it left me underwhelmed. There were a couple of good laughs, but I wished it had been funnier. I found Patty's third-person autobiography section to be unbelievable in terms of voice. Franzen, you can't just capitalize a few words here and there and call it someone's perspective! It was clearly just Franzen, being Franzen. I wished he would have truly tried to write as Patty would have. Really gone there. Why didn't he? Also, I found two anachronisms. It says that when she was a kid, Patty received remaindered books from Barnes and Noble as gifts from her grandparents. Um, era? Also, in Joey's 2001 section (stupidly in the 2004 section--did I misread something?), his aunt disparages Tina Fey and Sarah Silverman. But in 2001 Fey and Silverman weren't well known enough! I was annoyed by these slips, however small. There's one paragraph near the end that's truly exceptional and beautiful and moving. Otherwise, I wonder why this is considered a contemporary masterpiece. It's a fine, capable book--but it didn't amaze me. It's no Corrections....more

review: A few of these stories I liked very much, and Egan's talent is evident--you can see how she became the masterful writer she is today. But many of the A few of these stories I liked very much, and Egan's talent is evident--you can see how she became the masterful writer she is today. But many of the stories, for me, fell a little flat, or felt so classic as to seem formulaic. I forgot a lot of them as soon as I was done, whereas I can remember every chapter and character from Egan's new book, A Visit from the Goon Squad. This is a must-read if you are crazy for Egan, but not the book to start with if you are only just coming to her work. I think, with Look at Me, she really leaped into brilliance, and has stayed there ever since.It was nice to see how far Egan's skills have come since this first collection. Maybe there's hope for me after all......more

title: The Singer's Gun
author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really enjoyed this book! The prose is slick and clear as glass, and I loved the non-linear, mosaic-like structure, and the way Mandel presented a cI really enjoyed this book! The prose is slick and clear as glass, and I loved the non-linear, mosaic-like structure, and the way Mandel presented a character's memories with a simple phrase, word or name, followed by a colon, and then a description of such phrase, word or person. It was so elegant, even sexy. Lots of sexiness in this book, guys: naked girls, singers with guns, recording devices, criminal families, Italian islands and payphones, cats eating tuna in airport bathrooms...At first, I wasn't sure how I'd feel about the novel, as its premise felt a touch absurd/whimsical for my taste. Its main character, after all, is sent to wait out his work days in the 'dead files' room of the building's basement, and he just lives with it. But as the story gathered history and weight, I got really invested in the world and found it believable, if a little technicolored and poetic. And, in the end, I loved these qualities of the book, as it made everything feel heightened and lovely and deep in the way our lives often aren't in their quotidian accuracy. Sometimes, the book emphasized too much its themes, namely: work, feeling lost, disappearing. But I also enjoyed these themes, so I'm not sure how they might otherwise be handled. And perhaps this tight-grip on the deeper subject is a byproduct of the taut quality of the storytelling, which was really appealing. Seriously, I could not put this book down. And it was beautifully written to boot! My only real complaint with this book are its double prepositions. They drove me crazy! "She turned to him and pulled her nightgown off over her head" (84) would be so much graceful as, "She turned to him and pulled her nightgown over her head" And "Elena began walking forward across the room..." (202) would be sleeker as "Elena began walking across the room" and "Climbed up onto the breakwater rocks" (225) could be, "Climbed onto the breakwater rocks..." These double prepositions were all over the text, and my neurotic language-reader winced at each one. I am sure Mandel's next book, sans all the unnecessary prepositions, will be a masterpiece!Emily St. John Mandel is such a talent. Read this book and get pulled into this mysterious sexy bright dark world!...more

review: Many passages in this book were quite beautiful, and I was interested in how little we saw of the crime in the novel, around which everything revolvesMany passages in this book were quite beautiful, and I was interested in how little we saw of the crime in the novel, around which everything revolves. That was pretty cool.My main trouble with Brandon's novel is the characterization. It felt like these characters were made up of a series of arbitrary quirks. Shelby is into Jewish comics. Mr. Hibma (kept at a distance with his teacher-title throughout the book) gives his students posters of old movies. And? So what? When I described this characterization to Patrick, he said, "They sound less like characters and more like Facebook profiles." It's not that bad, but there is something to this analogy, for the soul is made up of more than a series of strange inclinations and obsessions. The book tells us these characters want more, want something--but the telling of those desires, the declaration of their existence, still doesn't accurately capture them in all their complexity and terror and beauty. The whole time I was reading this book, I was thinking, "I'm reading a book. I'm reading a book. I'm reading a book." It exhausted me. ...more

title: Maurice
author: Forster, E.M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was such a beautiful and moving book, and felt particularly modern for Forster--and not just because of the gay relationships depicted therein. TThis was such a beautiful and moving book, and felt particularly modern for Forster--and not just because of the gay relationships depicted therein. There was something spare to the writing here, it felt less embellished to me than the prose in his other novels. It also did away with the comedy of errors and parlor room dramatics of A Room with a View or Where Angels Fear to Tread, and that felt modern, too. I appreciated how Maurice could be quite frustrating, and that he wasn't all that smart. It's difficult to write a character like that, and still make the reader care about him. I also loved that he took a definitive stand at the end of the novel, his mind finally nimble enough to connect the self to what mattered to it--I loved to see "the muddle" of his mind fall away as he embraced his long-suffered-over sexuality.I can't give the book five stars because there were whole passages that confused me. At the beginning especially, Forster speaks in the abstract to the point of confusion. I felt like I wasn't getting a joke. Later, there were plot points or emotional shifts that I didn't understand as they were happening. For instance, I didn't realize until the very end that Maurice and Clive hadn't actually had sex--I assumed they had until it was revealed in the final chapter that they'd kept their relationship platonic. I had wrongly assumed the sex scenes had simply been implied. Silly me! I fault myself for his mistake, but even so, I was bothered, and there were other interactions and details about his schooling or whatever that went over my head. It's weird to read a giant talent like Forster and think, "This needs an edit" or "This could use some elaboration" but there you have it. Perhaps writing a book privately will produce a work of raw honesty and power, with the occasional obscure passage.The rhythm of the prose in this book took my breath away: "Drawing the curtains, he gazed long into the rain and sighed, and struck his own face, and bit his own lips." This reminds me a little of Thomas Hardy's sentences, and makes me swoon. ...more

review: What I loved about this novel was how full of heart it was. That sounds cheesy, I know, I know, but it's true. Narrator Sebastian is just earnest to hWhat I loved about this novel was how full of heart it was. That sounds cheesy, I know, I know, but it's true. Narrator Sebastian is just earnest to his soul (I suppose that's what happens when you're raised by your Nana in a geodesic dome), and you can't help but love his overly-formal speech and innocence about the world and his geometry skills and his bad hair and weird flannel shirt. The dialogue is terrific throughout--so funny and taut, particularly in the scenes between Jared and Sebastian--and I really loved the final talent show scene. I feared it would be predictable, and it wasn't, it let me just sit back and enjoy the drama as it unfolded.I do wish the book were a little more complicated. I thought perhaps there could have been a more subtle way to thread in the Buckminster Fuller stuff, for Sebastian to have a more nuanced relationship with this figure he's been raised to exalt. Also, I wanted the drama between the characters to get a little more complicated. This feels like a young adult novel at times--and that isn't a knock against it, it's just not what I prefer to read. I like my teenager tales to get a little darker. And this book, it's punk rock, but it ain't dark....more

title: Columbine
author: Cullen, Dave*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On Monday I spent 6 hours reading this book it was so utterly absorbing, terrifying, thoughtful and compassionate. I am amazed by the breadth and deptOn Monday I spent 6 hours reading this book it was so utterly absorbing, terrifying, thoughtful and compassionate. I am amazed by the breadth and depth of Cullen's research, and the facility with which he organized and presented it to the reader. The content is obviously daunting and difficult, but Cullen manages to show not only the what and where and who and how of the event, but the why--or, almost the why. Can such an act ever, really, be comprehensible? Cullen got as close as answering that as anyone will, I think. I felt such an incredible closeness to the people in this book, and I marveled at Cullen's compassion for everyone involved and affected by this tragedy: the victims, their families, the parents of the killers, the police force, the high school students past, present and future, and the county as a whole. I really understood, with this book, how a single day can reverberate and change the lives of so many people. My measly  isn't doing this book justice. God, I just want to buy Dave Cullen a drink and thank him for this incredible book. ...more
