title: The Golden Notebook
author: Lessing, Doris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I just found out Doris Lessing won the Nobel, and now I feel compelled to explain my one star  of her most famous book.My gal pals and I read thI just found out Doris Lessing won the Nobel, and now I feel compelled to explain my one star  of her most famous book.My gal pals and I read this over the course of a humid Iowa City summer, as part of a short lived and ill-conceived book club. We met once a week in a different apartment (though I can only imagine us at Kiki's place), to drink champagne and discuss the novel. Complain is really what we did--and then I went home with a champagne headache. None of us liked this novel, and I believe only a couple of us finished it. The Golden Notebook moves at a glacial pace, and it's probably the only book that has ever truly depressed me. Usually I like depressing books! This one just made me feel sick for humanity and myself, and for this terrible sad narrator writing these notebooks. The only good part to talk about, of course, was the orgasm section: is it true that the man who really loves you can give you both a clitoral AND a vaginal orgasm? Kiki told us her mom's opinion, and we all leaned in, attentive. But really, this too is an outdated discussion--if my memory serves me correctly (and it doesn't always), in the book, her lover refuses to believe that the clitoral orgasm is a real orgasm, and only wants to give her the other kind. I think nowadays men and women are more accepting of all orgasms. Yea for the world and the progress we've made! In the end, this book was a disappointment. My gal pals and I had more fun at the Iowa City Public Pool, which also was not fun....more

review: Yes, this novel starts out funny. But after about a hundred pages I wanted more than a fat Russian guy in a track suit rapping inane lyrics about his Yes, this novel starts out funny. But after about a hundred pages I wanted more than a fat Russian guy in a track suit rapping inane lyrics about his girlfriend from New York. Once the humor ran out (and it did), there was little left to hold the novel up. I feel guilty writing bad s, but I must fight against the unwarranted praise this book has received (Best Book of the Year? Please!). I liked Shteyngart's first novel, The Russian Debutante's Handbook, much better, and I read an interview with him where he said he wants to try something not so satirical for his next book. I hope this happens, because he's clearly a very talented writer. I mean, he did go to Oberlin after all......more

title: Remainder
author: McCarthy, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Judging from the ultra-high-concept premise, I should've known this novel wasn't right for me. A guy gets 8.5 million pounds in a settlement for an acJudging from the ultra-high-concept premise, I should've known this novel wasn't right for me. A guy gets 8.5 million pounds in a settlement for an accident he's not allowed to disclose (part of the settlement's agreement), and soon after gets the urge to re-enact an experience that feels like a vivid memory but isn't. This part of the book is pretty compelling and strange, but after that the novel simply depicts the narrator's thirst for one re-enactment after another as he falls farther and farther away from reality. I hated this guy--he reminded me of an eccentric millionare with a mental problem, a la Michael Jackson, except rather than create a theme park at his house to lure and fondle innocent children, and impregnate some woman and then name the child after himself and make him wear a blanket over his head, this guy forces all these people to create one set after another in attempt to feel all tingly while inside these performed movements. Who cares? Not me. I was initially interested in the book's ideas about authenticity, the fluidity, or lackthereof, between a thought and an action, between truth and an acted truth, but the novel never moved forward with these ideas. It took me a week to finish the last 50 pages....more

review: I read this, DeLillo's first book, because my husband said it was good. I'm a fan of Libra and White Noise, and an even bigger fan of Underworld, so II read this, DeLillo's first book, because my husband said it was good. I'm a fan of Libra and White Noise, and an even bigger fan of Underworld, so I thought, Why not? I couldn't stand this book. I don't remember much about it except that it reminded me of hanging out with pretentious 19-year-old boys who wax poetic about Baudrillard and Godard over cheap beers. I have yet to meet anyone who read and liked this book after the age of 25. I'm guessing those who liked this book after the age of 25 probably read it when it was published, when the ideas therein were still original. Now we have Coke commercials that resemble this novel's concept. Not DeLillo's fault, but still--he could've taken himself a little less seriously. ...more

title: The Children's Hospital
author: Adrian, Chris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay. So I brought this on a trip with me--lugged the damn thing across the country--only to barely open it. I admire Adrian's prose, and his ambitionOkay. So I brought this on a trip with me--lugged the damn thing across the country--only to barely open it. I admire Adrian's prose, and his ambition, and I like the marrying of the hyper-realist and the surreal in this novel, but it moved so slowly, and tediously, and I never wanted to read it. Finally, finally, after 276 pages, I gave up. I rarely do this, but I wanted so badly to read on my vacation. I wanted a good, juicy, smart, beautiful read. A good read! Anything to get some pages turned. I even went to Barnes & Ignoble, the only bookstore in the area, to buy a new book. I never go to chain bookstores, if I can help it. Bless Chris Adrian. I think other people will have more patience for this one than I did. ...more

title: The Girl Who Trod on a Loaf
author: Davis, Kathryn
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was exhilirating and difficult. The narrative moves through various storylines/eras and operas, building information slowly, often favoring This book was exhilirating and difficult. The narrative moves through various storylines/eras and operas, building information slowly, often favoring deliciously layered and confusing paragraphs over straightforward scene-making. I loved the feeling of not understanding how in the hell Davis put this story together. I was at her mercy, and I'll admit, sometimes I wasn't exactly clear how I got somewhere. Did it matter? I'm not sure.This book also includes some terrific words, from "eidolon" ("An abstract idea of a cake, a cake elevated to the realm of pure thought, a cake eidolon" (119)), to, "cerements" ("Unlike Lazarus, he rose without divine assistance, and then, trailing cerements, shuffled down the hall to the kitchen, where he came upon Gunhild kneading dough in the dark" (297)). Also: caracul, sphagnum, umbellula, tisanes.I realized that while I may know a lot of words to describe the abstract, Davis has an unrivaled collection of words to describe the physical world. If only I were so lucky....more
